div.p: A location or structure in the body, including tissues, regions, cavities, and spaces; for example, right elbow, or left ventricle of the heart. The BodyLocation includes code and optional qualifiers of anatomical side or direction. The body location can also be determined from one or more body landmarks. If the code for the body location includes laterality and/or anatomical direction, the corresponding attributes might be unnecessary. Note that BodyLocation is a data type, a reusable structure, not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how an address structure can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

description.value: A location or structure in the body, including tissues, regions, cavities, and spaces; for example, right elbow, or left ventricle of the heart. The BodyLocation includes code and optional qualifiers of anatomical side or direction. The body location can also be determined from one or more body landmarks. If the code for the body location includes laterality and/or anatomical direction, the corresponding attributes might be unnecessary. Note that BodyLocation is a data type, a reusable structure, not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how an address structure can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

definition.value: A location or structure in the body, including tissues, regions, cavities, and spaces; for example, right elbow, or left ventricle of the heart. The BodyLocation includes code and optional qualifiers of anatomical side or direction. The body location can also be determined from one or more body landmarks. If the code for the body location includes laterality and/or anatomical direction, the corresponding attributes might be unnecessary. Note that BodyLocation is a data type, a reusable structure, not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how an address structure can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

short.value: Code for the body location, optionally pre-coordinating laterality or direction.

definition.value: Code for the body location, optionally pre-coordinating laterality or direction.

short.value: Body side of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location on the other side of the body.

definition.value: Body side of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location on the other side of the body.

short.value: Orientation of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location in another orientation.

definition.value: Orientation of the body location, if needed to distinguish from a similar location in another orientation.

short.value: An anatomical landmark that helps determine a body location.

definition.value: An anatomical landmark that helps determine a body location.

Note that BodyLocation is a data type, a reusable structure, not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how an address structure can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).
